awd_titl_txt: SCC-PG Smart Septic Strategies: Data Integration to Manage Hidden Infrastructure Threats to Our Homes and Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
Residential systems collect and treat wastewater from home toilets, sinks, baths, and washing appliances and are a key component of the water infrastructure of the United States. Approximately one in four U.S. households relies on septic systems to treat their wastewater. Most of this vast hidden infrastructure is poorly maintained and periodically overloaded by periods of high water use and/or household leaks.  Improving the functionality of these systems will lead to significant improvements to public health and environmental quality by reducing the volumes of untreated or under-treated wastewater released into the environment, which in turn will reduce exposures to dangerous pathogens in groundwater and surface waters, improve aquatic ecosystem health by reducing excess nutrient discharges, and avoid economic losses of closed fishing areas and beaches associated with high bacterial levels in the water. The results of this project will ultimately enable the development of smart septic systems, improved infrastructure asset management, and reduced threats to homes, health, water supplies, and the natural environment.  

This project will be the first to integrate high quality data on household-scale water use and leak patterns from existing smart water meters, in situ sensor measurements of septic system behavior, automated processing of infrared (IR) aerial imagery that can show septic system failure, and continuous monitoring of septic contamination in community streams with water quality sensors to enable smart septic systems, infrastructure asset management, and reduced threats to homes, health, and water supplies. The project will also create innovative data analytics tools that will generate household water usage profile breakdowns for specific fixtures and appliances, and further detect, classify and quantify water leakages and the impact to septic tank failures.  The development of these processes and constituent technology will be performed in close collaboration with septic management and regulatory officials as the state, regional, and local level to ensure that the processes and products that result from this research will a meaningful real-world impact on this important and long-neglected issue.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Residential septic systems collect and treat wastewater from home toilets, sinks, baths, and washing appliances and are a key component of the water infrastructure of the United States. Approximately one in four U.S. households relies on septic systems to treat their wastewater. The onus of maintaining well-functioning septic infrastructure lies with the homeowners. Unfortunately, septic systems are like a black box and their failure caused by periods of high water use and/or household leaks is evident only when significant loss of residential and community infrastructure and threat to public health has already occurred. Even the most technologically updated homes lack the technology to regulate septic infrastructure functionality by altering water use since there is no such technology available yet. Experts and public health officials who develop educational and outreach material for septic system maintenance and translate best management to financially disadvantaged homeowners, also do not have any data on septic system functionality in response to water use and hence cannot develop targeted solutions to address environmental justice issues surrounding access to wastewater infrastructure. Collectively, this translates to the fate of approximately 4 billion gallons of sewage per day. Due to the unique management challenges of this vast underground hidden infrastructure and extreme local implications of failing systems, this problem requires a scalable community level solution.

 Towards this effort, this project was the first to integrate high quality data on household-scale water use and leak patterns from existing smart water meters, state of the art in situ monitoring sensor measurements of septic system behavior, automated processing of aerial imagery that can show septic system failure, and continuous monitoring of septic contamination in community streams with water quality sensors to enable smart septic systems, infrastructure asset management, and reduced threats to homes, health, and water supplies. The project also created innovative data analytics tools that generate household water usage profile breakdowns for specific fixtures and appliances, and further detect, classify and quantify water leakages and the impact to septic tank failures. Results from household surveys performed for septic system users showed the enthusiasm of homeowners to gain control over system functionality and avoid costs associated with a failed system. Data from pilot installations of smart septic showed that the threat of septic leach field failure increased with extreme weather and seasons and water use regulations by homeowners would need to be updated with changes in either of those variables. This is especially relevant in the backdrop of climate change induced uncertain and extreme weather patterns. The results from this study also showed that high resolution water use monitoring was very effective in detecting a water leak in homes and translated to variability in the septic effluent signature. The development of these approaches and technologies are being performed in close collaboration with septic management and regulatory officials as the state, regional, and local level to ensure that the processes and products that result from this research will a meaningful real-world impact on this important and long-neglected issue.

Improving the functionality of these systems can significantly improve public health and environmental quality by reducing the volumes of untreated or under-treated wastewater released into the environment, which in turn will reduce exposures to dangerous pathogens in groundwater and surface waters, improve the health of streams and lakes by reducing releases of excess nutrients, and avoid economic losses of closed fishing areas and beaches associated with high bacterial levels in the water. The results of this project support the development of smart septic systems, improved infrastructure asset management, and reduced threats to homes, health, water supplies, and the natural environment.
